name: Tomato
description: A juicy fruit often used as a vegetable in cooking.

nutrients.name: Lycopene
nutrients.benefit: Protects against heart disease and cancer

uses: Used in salads, sauces, and soups
Base for ketchup and chutneys
Eaten raw or cooked

name: Spinach
description: A leafy green vegetable packed with nutrients.

nutrients.name: Folate
nutrients.benefit: Important for cell growth and metabolism

uses: Used in salads, smoothies, and curries
Can be sautéed or steamed
Popular in palak paneer and quiches
tips: Avoid hot weather to prevent bolting
Water evenly and keep soil cool

name: Carrot
description: A root vegetable known for its crunch and sweetness.
uses: Eaten raw in salads
Used in soups, stews, and desserts
Made into juice or pickles
tips: Thin seedlings early to avoid crowding

name: Banana
description: A tropical fruit rich in energy and potassium.

nutrients.name: Potassium
nutrients.benefit: Regulates fluid balance and muscle function

nutrients.name: Vitamin B6
nutrients.benefit: Helps with metabolism and brain function

uses: Eaten raw as a snack
Used in smoothies, baking, and desserts
Dried for chips or powder
tips: Harvest when the fruit turns yellow-green

name: Coriander
description: An herb with flavorful leaves and seeds used in cooking.
uses: Used as garnish and flavoring in dishes
Seeds used in spices and masalas
Leaves used in chutneys and sauces

name: Brinjal (Eggplant)
description: A glossy purple vegetable often used in curries and stir-fries.
uses: Used in curries like baingan bharta
Fried, roasted, or grilled
Stuffed and baked
tips: Stake plants to support heavy fruit
Harvest when fruits are shiny and firm

name: Mango
description: A juicy tropical fruit known as the king of fruits.
uses: Eaten fresh or in smoothies
Used in desserts and pickles
Made into juices, chutneys, and jams
tips: Prune yearly for shape and fruiting

name: Pineapple
description: A tropical fruit with a tangy-sweet taste and spiky appearance.
uses: Eaten fresh or juiced
Used in salads and desserts
Grilled or cooked in savory dishes
tips: Plant in pots or raised beds
Harvest when fruit turns golden yellow

name: Mint
description: A refreshing herb known for its strong aroma and cooling effect.
uses: Used in teas, chutneys, and refreshing drinks
Flavoring in food and desserts
Used in traditional remedies for digestion
tips: Best grown in containers to control spreading

name: Papaya
description: A tropical fruit that is rich in enzymes and vitamins.
uses: Eaten raw or blended in smoothies
Used in salads and desserts
Green papaya used in curries and pickles
tips: Don’t overwater to avoid root rot

name: Cucumber
description: A cool, hydrating vegetable used fresh or in salads.

nutrients.name: Vitamin K
nutrients.benefit: Supports blood clotting and bone health

uses: Used in salads, raita, and sandwiches
Made into pickles
Used in skin treatments
tips: Train vines on trellises to save space

name: Ladyfinger (Okra)
description: A warm-season vegetable used in many Indian dishes.

nutrients.name: Folate
nutrients.benefit: Good for pregnancy and cell growth

uses: Used in bhindi masala and sambhar
Fried or curried
Also pickled
tips: Harvest when pods are 3–5 inches long
Use gloves to avoid skin irritation from sap

name: Lemon
description: A citrus fruit rich in Vitamin C, widely used for its tangy flavor and health benefits.

nutrients.name: Citric Acid
nutrients.benefit: Aids in digestion and kidney stone prevention

uses: Used in drinks, teas, and lemonades
Enhances flavor in food and desserts
Natural preservative and cleaner

name: Fenugreek (Methi)
description: A leafy green vegetable and spice known for its distinct aroma and health benefits.
uses: Used as leafy green vegetable
Seeds used in spices and pickles
Tea for digestion and diabetes
tips: Harvest leaves when young and tender
Thin out seedlings for better growth

name: Guava
description: A tropical fruit known for its sweet flavor and numerous health benefits.
uses: Eaten raw or juiced
Used in jams and jellies
Leaves used in herbal teas
tips: Prune to maintain shape and airflow
Keep soil moist but not waterlogged
Harvest when fruits are slightly soft

name: Pumpkin
description: A large fruit used in cooking, baking, and as animal feed.

nutrients.name: Beta-carotene
nutrients.benefit: Converted to Vitamin A, supports vision

uses: Used in curries, pies, and soups
Roasted or steamed
Seeds used as snack or in granola

name: Strawberry
description: A sweet, red fruit known for its juicy flavor and antioxidants.

nutrients.name: Folate
nutrients.benefit: Good for cell function and pregnancy

uses: Eaten raw, in desserts, smoothies, and salads
Used to make jam and syrups
Popular in cosmetics and skincare

name: Watermelon
description: A juicy fruit perfect for summer, packed with hydration and sweetness.
uses: Eaten fresh, in juices, and fruit salads
Used in coolers and smoothies
Seeds roasted as snacks
tips: Check tendrils near fruit for ripeness

name: Chili Pepper
description: A spicy fruit used to add heat and flavor to food.
uses: Used in curries, pickles, sauces
Dried and powdered into chili flakes
Medicinal use for pain relief
tips: Harvest when bright red for full heat

name: Bitter Gourd (Karela)
description: A bitter fruit known for its health benefits, especially in diabetes management.
uses: Used in curries and stir-fries
Juiced for health benefits
Used in traditional medicine
tips: Harvest when young for less bitterness
Train vines on trellises for better yield

name: Zucchini
description: A summer squash that is versatile in cooking and low in calories.
uses: Used in stir-fries, salads, and baking
Grilled or roasted as a side dish
Can be spiralized into noodles
tips: Harvest when small for best flavor
Mulch to retain moisture and suppress weeds

name: Wheat
description: A staple cereal grain used globally for making flour, bread, and more.
uses: Flour for bread, chapati, and pasta
Used in breakfast cereals
Straw for mulch or fodder
tips: Ensure full sunlight for better yield
Harvest when grains are golden and hard

name: Barley
description: A cereal grain used for food, animal feed, and brewing.
uses: Used in soups, salads, and bread
Fermented for beer production
Animal feed and health supplements
tips: Harvest when grains are hard and golden

name: Corn
description: A cereal plant that yields large grains, rich in carbs and essential nutrients.
uses: Consumed boiled, roasted, or ground into flour
Used in popcorn, tortillas, corn oil, and animal feed
tips: Plant in blocks for better pollination
Harvest when silk turns brown and kernels are full
Space plants 20–25 cm apart, rows 60–75 cm apart

name: Millet
description: A group of small-seeded grasses, used as food and fodder.
uses: Used in porridge, bread, and snacks
Animal feed and birdseed
tips: Harvest when grains are hard and golden

name: Sorghum
description: A drought-resistant cereal grain used for food and fodder.
uses: Used in porridge, bread, and snacks
Animal feed and biofuel
tips: Harvest when grains are hard and golden

name: Onion
description: A bulb vegetable used as a base flavor in many dishes, known for its strong aroma.
soil: Loose, well-drained soil rich in organic matter
uses: Used in cooking globally for flavor
Can be pickled or eaten raw
Used in traditional remedies
tips: Remove flower stalks to promote bulb growth
Plant 10–15 cm apart, 30 cm between rows

name: Garlic
description: A bulbous plant known for its strong flavor and health benefits.
uses: Used in cooking for flavor and aroma
Used in traditional medicine for various ailments
Can be pickled or fermented
tips: Harvest when leaves turn yellow and dry

name: Broccoli
description: A green cruciferous vegetable loaded with fiber, vitamins, and antioxidants.
water: Consistent moisture – don’t let soil dry
uses: Used in stir-fries, soups, and pastas
Eaten steamed or roasted
Great in salads or with dips
tips: Space plants 45 cm apart with 60 cm between rows

name: Cauliflower
description: A white cruciferous vegetable known for its versatility and health benefits.
soil: Well-drained, fertile soil rich in organic matter
uses: Used in stir-fries, soups, and salads
Can be roasted, steamed, or eaten raw
Used as a low-carb substitute for rice or pizza crust
tips: Protect heads from sun to prevent yellowing
Space plants 45 cm apart with 60 cm between rows

name: Cabbage
description: A leafy green vegetable used in salads, stir-fries, and fermented dishes.
soil: Well-drained, fertile soil rich in organic matter
uses: Used in salads, stir-fries, and soups
Fermented into sauerkraut or kimchi
Used as wraps or in coleslaw
tips: Harvest when heads are firm and tight
Space plants 30 cm apart with 60 cm between rows

name: Bell Pepper
description: A colorful, mild-tasting pepper rich in antioxidants and vitamin C.
soil: Well-drained, loamy soil rich in organic matter
uses: Used in salads, stir-fries, pizzas, and curries
Can be stuffed, roasted, or grilled
Adds color and crunch to dishes
tips: Harvest when firm and fully colored
Stake tall varieties to support weight
Plant 45 cm apart with 60 cm between rows

name: Green Gram
description: A short-duration legume crop grown for high-protein seeds and sprouts.
soil: Well-drained loamy or sandy loam soil
uses: Cooked whole, sprouted, or ground into flour
Used in soups, stews, and dosas
Improves soil fertility via nitrogen fixation
tips: Requires minimal fertilizer due to nitrogen-fixing roots
Use trellis for better airflow in humid areas
Plant 7–10 cm apart in rows 30 cm apart

name: Chili Pepper
description: A fiery fruit used in cuisines for heat and flavor, with many health benefits.
soil: Well-drained, fertile soil with good organic matter
uses: Used fresh, dried, or powdered in curries, sauces, and pickles
Medicinal use for topical pain relief
Preserved in oil or vinegar
tips: Harvest when fully red for most heat
Use gloves when handling spicy varieties
Space 45 cm apart with 60 cm between rows

name: Potato
description: A starchy root vegetable widely used in almost every cuisine.
soil: Loose, well-drained soil rich in organic matter
uses: Boiled, fried, baked, mashed, or curried
Used in chips, fries, soups, and snacks
Staple food in many countries
tips: Hill soil around plants as they grow to avoid green potatoes
Harvest after plants yellow and die back
Plant 30 cm apart with 60 cm between rows

name: Turmeric
description: A golden root known for its powerful anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties.
soil: Fertile, well-drained, sandy or loamy soil
uses: Used as a spice and natural dye
Medicinal use in teas and ointments
Essential in curries and golden milk
tips: Plant 30 cm apart in raised beds for drainage
Mulch to retain moisture and suppress weeds
Harvest when leaves turn yellow and dry

name: Radish
description: A crunchy root vegetable with a peppery flavor and fast-growing cycle.
water: Regular – keep soil moist but not soggy
soil: Loose, sandy soil free of stones

nutrients.name: Folate
nutrients.benefit: Helps in red blood cell formation

uses: Eaten raw, in salads, pickled, or stir-fried
Radish leaves are edible and nutritious
Used in soups and traditional dishes
tips: Thin plants early for proper bulb development
Keep soil loose for proper root expansion
Space 5–7 cm apart in rows 15 cm apart

name: Mustard
description: A fast-growing leafy green also cultivated for its spicy seeds.
soil: Rich, well-drained soil with neutral pH
uses: Leaves cooked or stir-fried
Seeds used in pickles and oil
Used for mustard condiments and spice
tips: Harvest leaves when young for best taste
Can be succession planted every 2 weeks
Space 10–15 cm apart in rows 30 cm apart

name: Ginger
description: An aromatic root used in culinary and medicinal applications across cultures.
uses: Used fresh, dried, or powdered in cooking
Used in teas and traditional medicines
Great in curries, sweets, and juices
tips: Use rhizomes with buds for planting
Space 20–25 cm apart in rows 30 cm apart

name: Basil
description: A fragrant herb used in Italian and Southeast Asian cuisines.
water: Moderate – water at base to avoid mildew
soil: Moist, well-drained soil with rich organic content
uses: Used in pesto, sauces, salads, and teas
Flavoring for oils and dressings
Fresh garnish for soups and pizzas
tips: Pinch flowers to promote leaf growth
Harvest regularly to encourage new shoots
Space 20–30 cm apart in rows 30–40 cm apart

name: Tulsi
description: A sacred medicinal herb known for its immunity-boosting and adaptogenic properties.
water: Moderate – allow topsoil to dry slightly between watering
uses: Used in herbal teas and Ayurvedic medicine
Natural remedy for coughs, colds, and stress
Used in religious rituals in India
tips: Pinch top leaves to encourage bushiness
Keep in a sunny, warm spot
Plant 30 cm apart in rows 40 cm apart

name: Amaranth
description: An ancient pseudo-cereal cultivated for both its protein-rich seeds and leafy greens, used in traditional diets across the world.
water: Low to Moderate – drought tolerant once established
soil: Well-drained soil, tolerates poor or marginal soils
climate: Tropical to subtropical, prefers warm and dry conditions
harvestTime: Summer for leaves, late summer to early autumn for seeds

nutrients.name: Protein
nutrients.benefit: Supports growth and repair of tissues

nutrients.name: Lysine
nutrients.benefit: Amino acid important for immune function

uses: Leaves eaten in curries, stir-fries, or steamed
Seeds popped or ground into flour for porridge or flatbreads
Used in traditional fasting foods in many cultures
tips: Harvest leaves when young for tenderness
Allow seeds to fully mature on plant before harvest
Space 20–25 cm apart; thin early for best seed heads
